prior_works.title: Distributed Cooperative Decision-Making in Multiarmed Bandits
prior_works.authors: Per Landgren, Vaibhav Srivastava, Naomi Ehrich Leonard
prior_works.role: Introduced decentralized cooperative UCB-style algorithms where agents share information over a communication graph using (running) consensus, and derived regret that depends on network connectivity.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper generalizes Landgren et al.’s consensus-UCB template to time-dependent random graphs and agent-heterogeneous arm rewards, adding a new weighting scheme to correct for information distortion due to random connectivity.

prior_works.title: Decentralized Exploration in Multi-Armed Bandits
prior_works.authors: Fernando Martínez-Rubio, Varun Kanade, Paolo Rebeschini
prior_works.role: Analyzed finite-time decentralized bandit algorithms on networks, linking regret to spectral properties and employing communication protocols (e.g., accelerated gossip) for efficient information sharing.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present work builds on the network-centric regret viewpoint of Martínez-Rubio et al., but extends it to random, time-varying graphs and introduces a UCB-with-weighting mechanism robust to stochastic topology changes.

prior_works.title: Distributed Cooperative Learning in Multi-Armed Bandits
prior_works.authors: Sattar Shahrampour, Alexander Rakhlin, Ali Jadbabaie
prior_works.role: Proposed consensus-based information fusion (e.g., distributed Thompson sampling) for bandits over networks, demonstrating how local posteriors/estimates can be aggregated despite communication constraints.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Xu and Klabjan adopt the consensus-fusion paradigm from this line of work but convert it into a frequentist UCB framework augmented with novel weights to handle randomness in the communication graph.

prior_works.title: Randomized Gossip Algorithms
prior_works.authors: Stephen Boyd, Arpita Ghosh, Balaji Prabhakar, Devavrat Shah
prior_works.role: Established foundations for averaging/consensus via randomized gossip on networks, including convergence rates under random, time-varying communication patterns.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The averaging-based consensus step in the proposed algorithm and its analysis of mixing/averaging under random graphs directly leverage the principles and guarantees of randomized gossip.

prior_works.title: Bandits with Heavy Tail
prior_works.authors: Sébastien Bubeck, Nicolò Cesa-Bianchi, Gábor Lugosi
prior_works.role: Developed robust mean-estimation and confidence-bound techniques (e.g., truncated or MOM estimators) to extend UCB-style algorithms to heavy-tailed/sub-exponential reward distributions.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s UCB-type indices that handle both sub-Gaussian and sub-exponential rewards are grounded in robust confidence constructions introduced by Bubeck et al.

prior_works.title: On Random Graphs
prior_works.role: Introduced the Erdős–Rényi random graph model, a canonical framework for analyzing connectivity and mixing properties in randomly generated networks.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The environment-driven random communication graphs and the paper’s graph-simulation component explicitly rely on ER-style random graph modeling and its connectivity/mixing regimes.

synthesis_narrative:
The core innovation of Xu and Klabjan is a decentralized UCB-type framework that remains effective under (i) time-dependent random communication graphs and (ii) heterogeneous arm rewards across agents, while accommodating both sub-Gaussian and sub-exponential reward tails. This builds directly on the consensus-UCB paradigm of decentralized bandits (Landgren et al.), where agents share statistics via network averaging, and on finite-time graph-sensitive analyses (Martínez-Rubio et al.) that tied regret to spectral properties. Prior consensus-based distributed bandit methods (e.g., Shahrampour et al.) established how local posteriors/estimates can be fused despite communication constraints; the present work retains the averaging machinery but introduces a new weighting scheme to debias and stabilize information aggregation when the topology itself is random and time-varying.
Foundational results on randomized gossip averaging (Boyd et al.) underpin the paper’s averaging-consensus step and provide the convergence tools needed to reason about mixing over stochastic graphs. To address heavy-tailed or sub-exponential rewards, the algorithm’s UCB indices draw on robust confidence constructions from Bubeck, Cesa-Bianchi, and Lugosi, ensuring valid exploration bonuses beyond the sub-Gaussian regime. Finally, modeling and simulation of the environment-provided random graphs leverage classical Erdős–Rényi random graph theory (and related rapidly mixing Markov-chain sampling ideas referenced by the authors), which informs connectivity and mixing-time regimes assumed in their analysis. Together, these works supply the consensus mechanisms, regret-sensitive network analysis, robust UCB machinery, and random-graph modeling that the paper integrates and extends to deliver decentralized learning guarantees under randomness in both rewards and communication topology.
